# Accessibility {#sec-accessibility}




::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code}
library(tidyverse)
library(sonify)
set.seed(8675309)
```
:::




## Visual Impairment

Here is some code to simulate different relationships.




::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code}
dat <- tibble(
  x = seq(-3, 3, .01),
) |>
  mutate(
    none = rnorm(n()),
    linear_pos = x + rnorm(n()),
    linear_neg = -x + rnorm(n()),
    quadratic = x^2 + rnorm(n()),
    category = sample(c("control", "experimental"), n(), TRUE)
  )
```
:::





### Sonify

@siegert2017sonify

No relationship sounds like a steady or randomly wavering tone.




::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(dat, aes(x = x, y = none)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth()
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
`geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula = 'y ~ x'
```


:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](app-accessibility_files/figure-html/fig-none-1.png){#fig-none fig-align='center' fig-alt='A scatterplot with \'x\' on the x axis with range -3 to 3, and \'none\' on the y-axis with range -3 to 3. There are 601 points (solid black circles) and a trendline at about y = 0 that curves up slightly at both ends.' width=100%}
:::
:::

::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code}
sonify(dat$x, dat$none)
```
:::





A linear positive relationship sounds like an increasing tone.




::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(dat, aes(x = x, y = linear_pos)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth()
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
`geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula = 'y ~ x'
```


:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](app-accessibility_files/figure-html/fig-linear-pos-1.png){#fig-linear-pos fig-align='center' fig-alt='A scatterplot with \'x\' on the x axis with range -3 to 3, and \'linear_pos\' on the y-axis with range -6 to 6. There are 601 points (solid black circles) and a trendline with a slope of 1 (from -3, -3 to 3, 3). Points are spread out about +/- 2 from the trendline).' width=100%}
:::
:::

::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code}
sonify(dat$x, dat$linear_pos)
```
:::




A linear negative relationship sounds like a decreasing tone.




::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(dat, aes(x = x, y = linear_neg)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth()
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
`geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula = 'y ~ x'
```


:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](app-accessibility_files/figure-html/fig-linear-neg-1.png){#fig-linear-neg fig-align='center' fig-alt='A scatterplot with \'x\' on the x axis with range -3 to 3, and \'linear_neg\' on the y-axis with range -6 to 6. There are 601 points (solid black circles) and a trendline with a slope of -1 (from -3, 3, to 3, -3). Points are spread out about +/- 2 from the trendline).' width=100%}
:::
:::

::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code}
sonify(dat$x, dat$linear_neg)
```
:::




This quadratic relationship decreases in pitch and then increases.




::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(dat, aes(x = x, y = quadratic)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth()
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
`geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula = 'y ~ x'
```


:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](app-accessibility_files/figure-html/fig-quadratic-1.png){#fig-quadratic fig-align='center' fig-alt='A scatterplot with \'x\' on the x axis with range -3 to 3, and \'linear_neg\' on the y-axis with range -12 to 10. There are 601 points (solid black circles) and a trendline with a U-shaped quadratic pattern starting about -3, 8, with a lowest point of 0, 0, and ending about 3, 8. Points are spread out about +/- 2 from the trendline).' width=100%}
:::
:::

::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code}
sonify(dat$x, dat$quadratic)
```
:::




### BrailleR

[BrailleR](https://ajrgodfrey.github.io/BrailleR/) @godfrey2020brailler




::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code}
# BrailleR was removed from CRAN recently, if it's not back, try
# remotes::install_github("ajrgodfrey/BrailleR")
library(BrailleR)
```
:::

::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(dat, aes(x = x, y = linear_neg)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth()
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stderr}

```
`geom_smooth()` using method = 'loess' and formula = 'y ~ x'
```


:::

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
This is an untitled chart with no subtitle or caption.
It has x-axis '' with labels -2, 0 and 2.
It has y-axis '' with labels -6, -3, 0, 3 and 6.
It has 2 layers.
Layer 1 is a set of 601 big solid circle points of which about 93% can be seen.
Layer 2 is a 'lowess' smoothed curve with 95% confidence intervals covering 2.9% of the graph.
```


:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](app-accessibility_files/figure-html/fig-linear-neg-2-1.png){#fig-linear-neg-2 fig-align='center' fig-alt='A scatterplot with \'x\' on the x axis with range -3 to 3, and \'linear_neg\' on the y-axis with range -6 to 6. There are 601 points (solid black circles) and a trendline with a slope of -1 (from -3, 3, to 3, -3). Points are spread out about +/- 2 from the trendline).' width=100%}
:::
:::





You can see it doesn't alway get everything right. It only readds the axis labels if they have been explicitly set.




::: {.cell layout-align="center"}

```{.r .cell-code}
ggplot(dat, aes(x = category, y = quadratic, fill = category)) +
  geom_violin(show.legend = FALSE) +
  labs(x = "Category",
       y = "Score")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}

```
This is an untitled chart with no subtitle or caption.
It has x-axis 'Category' with labels control and experimental.
It has y-axis 'Score' with labels 0, 4 and 8.
The chart is a violin graph that VI cannot process.
```


:::

::: {.cell-output-display}
![](app-accessibility_files/figure-html/fig-violin-1.png){#fig-violin fig-align='center' fig-alt='A violin plot with \'category\' on the x-axis and labels \'contol\' and \'experimental\', and `quadratic\' on the y-axis with range -2 to 12. Two white shapes show the distribution, which is bottom-heavy and ranging from about -2 to 9 for both categories with no obvious difference.' width=100%}
:::
:::
